Situation1: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The regular weekly religious education class for the parish's children is scheduled.
Story: I stared at the calendar on my desk, the two appointments circled in red. As a police officer, I was expected to testify in court that afternoon—my duty to uphold justice, to speak the truth, to ensure fairness for all. The subpoena was clear: my presence was not optional. Yet, as a priest, I was also expected to lead the weekly religious education class for the children of my parish. Parents trusted me to guide their children, to nurture their faith, to be present and reliable. Both roles demanded my integrity, my time, my undivided attention. I felt the weight of their expectations pressing down on me, the fear of letting someone down gnawing at my conscience. I could already imagine the disappointment in the children’s eyes if I canceled, the frustration of the court if I failed to appear. My heart pounded as I sat at my desk, torn between two worlds, each calling me to serve, each unwilling to wait.
